Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Nicholas K. Salter is "Surface Bundles, Mapping Class Groups, and Moduli of Riemann Surfaces." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Joseph Harris.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report concerns the NSF PostDoctoral Research Fellowship held from the period 7/1/17- 6/30/20. The title of the project is "Surface bundles, mapping class groups, and moduli of Riemann surfaces". Research was conducted in the mathematical disciplines of topology, group theory, and algebraic geometry. Additional resources furnished by the award were directed towards mentoring and training the next generation of mathematicians. 

To explain what mathematical developments resulted from the award, we begin with an analogy. Recall the Möbius strip is constructed by taking a rectangle and gluing a pair of opposite ends together with a twist. We can imagine doing this with a piece of lined paper, gluing parallel to the lined direction: in this way, we can view the Möbius strip as a family of lines. As we travel perpendicular to the lines ("around the loop" in the Möbius strip), we give a mathematical description of its structure: the Möbius strip is a family of lines "over the circle" - meaning that we have one line for each point on the circle running through the middle of the strip.

There is of course a second object one can build by gluing parallel ends of a rectangle togther. If one does not twist, the result is just a cylinder. This is also a family of lines over the circle. The essential difference between the cylinder and the Möbius strip is in the "gluing instructions": whether or not you choose to twist as you glue. 

Modern mathematics is chock-full of spatial structures (usually higher-dimensional) that share this same basic structure with the Möbius strip and the cylinder: they are constructed by taking some relatively simple structure (a single line, in the case of the Möbius strip), and "weaving" these together over some sort of "base space" (the circle, for the Möbius strip) to make an object with a simple local structure (just a packet of lines), but with a more complicated global "topology". These are called fiber bundles. 

This project studied some especially important examples of fiber bundles, called surface bundles. Now instead of starting with a one-dimensional object (the line), we start with a two-dimensional object, like the surface of a sphere. "In nature" (that is to say, in the other parts of mathematics where these structures naturally arise), in fact it is much more common for the surfaces to be substantially more complicated than spheres: they are "higher-genus", meaning that the surfaces have many holes in them. 

Whereas there are only two ways to complete the rectangle by gluing ends (either twist while gluing, or don't), there are infinitely many different ways to glue a surface back onto itself. The collection of all of these "gluing instructions" is called the mapping class group. This is a highly-structured mathematical object known as a group, meaning that there is an "arithmetic" for gluing instructions; essentially, this is a reflection of the fact that combining two gluing instructions in sequence results in a third. 

One of the major outcomes of this project was to investigate a previously-unexplored special class of gluing instructions (in technical language, we studied r-spin and framed mapping class groups). The major achievement here was to identify a set of "prime numbers" for these gluing instructions, which is to say that we found a special collection of gluing instructions from which all gluing instructions arise by combining these in different proportions.

From this foundational result, we were able to obtain substantial new insights into the structure of some surface bundles that play important roles in other parts of mathematics. In such a brief summary it is unfortunately not possible to explain in detail what these bundles are, why they are important, and what we were able to learn about them. To provide a very short synopsis: the families we studied are various different kinds of "master blueprints": they contain the instructions to build all possible bundles arising from certain constructions. For instance, one of our major applications was to the setting of "translation surfaces", a special kind of surface built, much like a Möbius strip, by gluing together sides on a flat piece of paper. We were also able to study surface bundles arising as solutions to algebraic equations. Our basic achievement here was to, in effect, describe the gluing instructions for these master blueprints. 

As a complement to the research portions of the award, we devoted substantial energy to the mentoring of high school and college students. In sumer 2019 we directed a one-on-one reading course with a very talented former student. We have also been supervising an independent research project with a former local high school student, now a rising sophomore at MIT. In addition to giving a number of one-off lectures to students, we also began planning for a research program in Summer 2020.
